title.rendered: Explore Job Roles: Air Traffic Controllers

content.rendered:
What is an Air Traffic Controller?

Air Traffic Controllers are generally in charge of the safety of the aircraft. They are the ones that manage the flow of traffic in an airspace and direct the pilots during takeoff and landing.

Where does an Air Traffic Controller work?

  • Federal Aviation Administration (FAA)
  • Control towers

How much do Air Traffic Controllers make?

Based on real new grad salaries reported through Handshake, the median annual salary for an Air Traffic Controller is $54,163.

What majors are typically interested in becoming Air Traffic Controllers?

One’s major doesn’t necessarily determine their career, but these are some common majors of those who end up pursuing Air Traffic Controller jobs.

  • Aviation management majors
  • Engineering majors
Explore Air Traffic Controller job opportunities on Handshake.

Air Traffic Controllers skills and competencies:

On top of a relevant degree and formal training, here are some professional skills that can help aspiring Air Traffic Controllers succeed in their work:

  • Quick analysis skills
  • Strong communication
  • Problem-solving skills

What are some common questions about Air Traffic Controllers?

Q: How to become an Air Traffic Controller?

A: While there are a few paths to becoming an air traffic controller, for the most common paths you’ll first either need an accredited degree from the Air Traffic Collegiate Training Initiative or a bachelor’s degree from a four-year university.
